title: Which one is correct, two and two make four, or two makes four? - Quora

response.answer_text: Two plus two is four. ( Plus, anyway, is not conjunction.) Two two's makes four. (We take two two's as a single subject and the interpretation goes like this (two two's ) makes four. Two and two is four. (Singular verbs are possible after plural number subjects in spoken calculations -Michael Swan.) ‘Ten times is fifty’. (Also,Two and two being an arithmetic formula, is taken as a single entity.) Two and two makes four. (1. Two and two taken as a single entity. 2. One of the definitions of ‘and’ according to Oxford dictionary is, ‘to connect two numbers to indicate that they are being added together’. ‘Six and four makes ten’.) In fact, I'd say that both singular and plural forms are correct. And that you are not going to be laughed at for saying either of them.

It’s easy when you imply the upstate “The sum of” to precede the addition. Like: (The sum of) two and two is four (The sum of ) ten and ten is twenty. But two of this and two of that are four in all. and Ten nuts and ten bolts make twenty pieces of hardware. No confusion.
